title: Assessing Information Security: Strategies, Tactics, Logic and Framework
author: Alexander Vladimirov, Konstantin Gavrilenko, Alexey Mikhaylovsky
summary: This book provides a practical framework and methodology for assessing information security within organizations. It offers insight into threats, controls, and the logic behind security management strategies, suitable for security professionals, auditors, and executives.

title: Adaptive Security Management Architecture
author: James S. Tiller
summary: Building on his previous work in security architecture, James S. Tiller presents a practical and adaptive framework for managing security in dynamic business environments. The book explores how to align security practices with constantly evolving organizational needs, including threat modeling, governance, and strategic planning.

title: Black Hat Python, 2nd Edition: Python Programming for Hackers and Pentesters
author: Justin Seitz, Tim Arnold
summary: This updated edition of the best-selling Black Hat Python dives deeper into using Python for hacking and penetration testing. Covering offensive tools such as network sniffers, exploit development, stealth techniques, and more, it equips hackers and pentesters with practical scripts and tactics for real-world scenarios.

title: Official Certified Ethical Hacker Review Guide
author: Kimberly Graves
summary: This guide offers a concise and targeted review for individuals preparing for the Certified Ethical Hacker (CEH) exam. Covering essential exam domains including footprinting, scanning, enumeration, and exploitation, the book provides review questions, real-world scenarios, and exam tips tailored to EC-Council objectives.

title: Coding for Penetration Testers: Building Better Tools
author: Jason Andress, Ryan Linn
summary: A practical guide for penetration testers and red teamers to develop custom security tools. This book covers scripting, automation, and tool development using Python and other languages to enhance efficiency and effectiveness in offensive security operations.

title: CompTIA PenTest+ Practice Test: Exam PT0-001
author: Crystal Panek, Robb Tracy
summary: This book provides hundreds of practice questions and answer explanations to prepare candidates for the CompTIA PenTest+ PT0-001 certification exam. It covers key objectives like planning, reconnaissance, scanning, exploitation, and post-exploitation analysis.

title: CompTIA Security+ SY0-701
author: Lewis Heuermann
summary: This study guide provides comprehensive coverage of the CompTIA Security+ SY0-701 exam objectives. It includes real-world examples, review questions, and exam tips to prepare learners for careers in cybersecurity. Topics include threat detection, risk management, secure network architecture, identity and access management, and more.

title: How the Cloud Upended Security: Misconfiguration and Control Plane Compromise Risk
author: Snyk
summary: This white paper outlines how cloud-native environments have reshaped security paradigms, exposing new risks such as misconfiguration and control plane compromise. Snyk proposes a five-pronged strategic approach to address these challenges, focusing on secure design, developer empowerment, policy as code, and outcome-based measurement.
notes:
Includes the 'Five Fundamentals':
F1: Know your environment
F2: Focus on prevention and secure design
F3: Empower your developers
F4: Align and automate with policy as code
F5: Measure what matters

title: Cybersecurity and Privacy Law Handbook: A Beginner’s Guide to Dealing with Privacy and Security While Keeping Hackers at Bay
author: Walter Rocchi
summary: This beginner-friendly guide explores the intersection of cybersecurity, data protection, and privacy law. Covering regulations like GDPR and HIPAA, it helps readers understand compliance obligations while offering practical advice on securing digital assets against threats. Ideal for IT professionals, business leaders, and legal practitioners entering the cybersecurity space.

title: Cybersecurity – Attack and Defense Strategies, Second Edition: Counter Modern Threats and Employ State-of-the-Art Tools and Techniques to Protect Your Organization Against Cybercriminals
author: Yuri Diogenes, Erdal Ozkaya
summary: This second edition delivers an updated playbook for red and blue team operations, providing techniques to detect, analyze, and respond to cyber threats. The book emphasizes hands-on strategies for identifying attack surfaces, strengthening defenses, and building incident response capabilities using current industry tools.

title: Cybersecurity Myths and Misconceptions: Avoiding the Hazards and Pitfalls that Derail Us
author: Eugene H. Spafford, Leigh Metcalf, Josiah Dykstra
summary: This book challenges long-held but flawed assumptions in cybersecurity, offering a fresh and deeply informed perspective on how the field really operates. With insight from seasoned experts, it covers policy, technical practices, and human behavior, exposing the myths that commonly lead organizations astray.
notes: Includes illustrations by Pattie Spafford.

title: Cybersecurity Ops with Bash: Attack, Defend, and Analyze from the Command Line
author: Paul Troncone, Carl Albing
summary: This book teaches security professionals how to use Bash scripting to build tools for offense, defense, and analysis. Covering topics like scanning, log analysis, and file manipulation, it demonstrates how the command line can be a powerful tool in cybersecurity operations.

title: Cybersecurity: The Beginner's Guide – A Comprehensive Guide to Getting Started in Cybersecurity
author: Dr. Erdal Ozkaya
summary: This book introduces the essential concepts, tools, and practices of cybersecurity for beginners. It covers topics such as threat landscapes, ethical hacking, malware, incident response, and cybersecurity careers, helping readers build a strong foundation in both technical and strategic aspects of the field.

title: Data Breaches: Crisis and Opportunity
author: Sherri Davidoff
summary: This book provides a deep dive into the lifecycle of data breaches, from the technical causes to the organizational response and recovery. Drawing on real-world cases, it offers insights into incident detection, legal and reputational risks, and how companies can transform breach experiences into stronger security practices.

title: Database and Application Security: A Practitioner’s Guide
author: R. Sarma Danturthi
summary: This book offers a comprehensive approach to securing databases and applications, focusing on practical strategies and real-world implementations. Covering topics such as encryption, access control, threat modeling, and security architecture, it provides actionable guidance for security professionals, developers, and architects.

title: Designing and Developing Secure Azure Solutions
author: Michael Howard, Heinrich Gantenbein, Simone Curz
summary: This book provides a comprehensive guide to designing secure solutions on Microsoft Azure. It covers core architectural principles, identity and access management, encryption, threat modeling, and secure development practices tailored to the Azure platform. Intended for architects, developers, and security engineers building cloud-native applications.
notes: Library of Congress Control Number: 2022947556

title: Effective Cybersecurity: Understanding and Using Standards and Best Practices
author: William Stallings
summary: This book bridges the gap between cybersecurity theory and real-world application by explaining how to implement and evaluate standards such as NIST, ISO/IEC 27001, COBIT, and more. Designed for practitioners, it provides actionable guidance for securing systems, networks, and operations based on proven best practices.

title: Ethical Hacking: A Hands-on Introduction to Breaking In
author: Daniel G. Graham
summary: This hands-on guide teaches the fundamentals of ethical hacking through practical exercises and modern tools. Covering topics such as networking, reconnaissance, buffer overflows, web hacking, and privilege escalation, it's ideal for learners seeking a strong, technical foundation in offensive security.

title: Ethical Hacking Student Guide
author: Internet Security Systems, Inc.
summary: A foundational student guide used in ISS's early ethical hacking training programs. This manual covers core topics such as network vulnerabilities, reconnaissance, exploitation techniques, and defense strategies as they were understood in the early 2000s. It reflects the state of cybersecurity education at the turn of the millennium.
notes: Print Date: September 21, 2000. ISS was based in Atlanta, GA, and later acquired by IBM. Training materials were often proprietary and distributed in instructor-led courses.

title: How to Hack Like a Ghost: Breaching the Cloud
author: Sparc Flow
summary: This red team field manual, written in a story-driven style, walks readers through stealthy attacks on cloud infrastructure. It simulates real-world adversarial techniques used to breach modern environments, focusing on evasion, lateral movement, and data exfiltration in cloud systems.

title: In Zero Trust We Trust
author: Avinash Naduvath
summary: This book provides a comprehensive approach to designing and implementing Zero Trust architectures, with a focus on Cisco technologies and enterprise use cases. Covering identity, segmentation, continuous validation, and policy enforcement, it helps security professionals adopt a Zero Trust mindset and align their infrastructure to modern threat models.
notes: Author is a CCIE Security (#59092). Published by Cisco Press.

title: Information Privacy Engineering and Privacy by Design: Understanding Privacy Threats, Technology, and Regulations Based on Standards and Best Practices
author: Dr. William Stallings
summary: This book provides a systematic approach to engineering privacy into systems using standards such as NIST and ISO/IEC. It covers privacy threats, technologies, legal and regulatory frameworks (like GDPR), and best practices for implementing Privacy by Design in real-world systems.

title: Learn Ethical Hacking from Scratch: Your Stepping Stone to Penetration Testing
author: Zaid Sabih
summary: This book introduces ethical hacking in a practical, beginner-friendly way. Covering a wide range of topics including network hacking, gaining access, post exploitation, and website hacking, it emphasizes real-world applications with step-by-step labs that mirror professional penetration testing workflows.

title: Microsoft Azure Network Security
author: Nicholas DiCola, Anthony Roman
summary: This book offers a comprehensive guide to securing network infrastructure in Microsoft Azure. It covers virtual networking, firewalls, private endpoints, DDoS protection, monitoring, and policy enforcement. Designed for security engineers and cloud architects, it maps Azure-native tools to Zero Trust and defense-in-depth strategies.

title: Microsoft Defender for Cloud
author: Yuri Diogenes, Tom Janetscheck
summary: This book provides a comprehensive guide to using Microsoft Defender for Cloud to secure Azure, hybrid, and multicloud environments. It covers posture management, threat detection, compliance, and workload protection using Defender's full feature set, with step-by-step configuration and best practices.

title: Microsoft Sentinel: Planning and Implementing Microsoft's Cloud-Native SIEM Solution, Second Edition
author: Yuri Diogenes, Nicholas DiCola, Tiander Turpijn
summary: This updated edition provides a comprehensive guide to planning, deploying, and managing Microsoft Sentinel, Microsoft's cloud-native SIEM and SOAR platform. It covers architecture design, data connectors, analytics rules, workbooks, automation, and incident response workflows, making it essential for SOC teams and Azure security engineers.

title: Microsoft Windows Security Essentials
author: Microsoft Learning / MTA Series
summary: Part of the Microsoft Technology Associate (MTA) certification series, this book introduces the foundational concepts of Windows security. It covers basic security principles, OS-level protections, user access control, network security, and malware defense, preparing readers for entry-level roles or further Microsoft certifications.
notes: Originally aligned with the MTA Security Fundamentals (Exam 98-367). MTA certification has since been retired.

title: The Modern Security Operations Center: The People, Process, and Technology for Operating SOC Services
author: Joseph Muniz
summary: This book provides a detailed roadmap for designing, implementing, and operating a modern Security Operations Center (SOC). Covering topics such as SOC maturity models, people and roles, incident response, technology stacks, and operational workflows, it offers strategic and technical guidance for teams building or improving SOC services.

title: Network Security: Private Communication in a Public World, Third Edition
author: Charlie Kaufman, Radia Perlman, Mike Speciner
summary: A widely respected guide to the principles and practice of network security, this third edition covers cryptography, secure protocols, internet threats, authentication, and more. Updated to include modern topics like quantum-resistant algorithms and contemporary security challenges, it remains a go-to reference for both students and professionals.

title: Network Security Essentials: Applications and Standards, Fourth Edition
author: William Stallings
summary: This book introduces key concepts in network security including encryption, authentication, public key infrastructure, and secure applications. Tailored for students and early-career professionals, the fourth edition reflects current standards and practices in applied cryptography and security protocols.

title: OAuth2 and OpenID Connect: The Professional Guide – Beta
author: Vittorio Bertocci
summary: This professional guide explores OAuth2 and OpenID Connect in depth, clarifying how these protocols enable secure authorization and authentication in modern applications. Authored by industry expert Vittorio Bertocci and curated by Andrea Chiarelli, the beta version offers detailed insights into flows, tokens, scopes, and best practices.
notes: Beta release. Curated by Andrea Chiarelli. Originally distributed through Auth0's developer portal.

title: Practical Cyber Intelligence: How Action-Based Intelligence Can Be an Effective Response to Incidents
author: Wilson Bautista Jr.
summary: This book explores the fundamentals of cyber threat intelligence (CTI) with a focus on real-world application in enterprise environments. It covers intelligence lifecycle models, collection methods, threat modeling, and how to integrate intelligence-driven decision-making into incident response and security operations.

title: A Practical Guide to Digital Forensics Investigations
author: Dr. Darren R. Hayes
summary: This guide provides in-depth instruction on conducting digital forensic investigations, covering topics such as evidence collection, preservation, analysis, and reporting. It includes case studies, tools, and methodologies applicable to law enforcement, corporate investigations, and cybersecurity incident response.

title: Practical Intrusion Analysis: Prevention and Detection for the Twenty-First Century
author: Ryan Trost
summary: This book provides detailed instruction on intrusion detection and prevention, with a focus on building an analyst’s intuition and technical capability. It covers IDS/IPS technologies, packet analysis, log correlation, and attack patterns, offering guidance for designing effective detection strategies and incident response plans.

title: Ransomware and Cyber Extortion: Response and Prevention
author: Sherri Davidoff, Matt Durrin, Karen Sprenger
summary: This book provides a comprehensive playbook for preparing for, detecting, responding to, and recovering from ransomware and cyber extortion incidents. It includes insights into attacker tactics, negotiation considerations, incident response coordination, and long-term prevention strategies.

title: Real-World Cryptography
author: David Wong
summary: This practical guide demystifies modern cryptographic systems and explains how cryptography is used in real-world applications. Topics include symmetric and asymmetric encryption, secure communication protocols, cryptographic APIs, key exchange, and post-quantum cryptography. Written for developers and security engineers, it balances conceptual clarity with actionable insights.

title: Secret Key Cryptography: Ciphers, from Simple to Unbreakable
author: Frank Rubin
summary: This book offers an in-depth and approachable guide to secret key cryptography, exploring the evolution of ciphers from historical substitutions to unbreakable modern algorithms. It includes hands-on examples, code, and challenges, making it suitable for students, hobbyists, and anyone interested in classical and symmetric cryptographic methods.
notes: Foreword by Randall K. Nichols.

title: Securing 5G and Evolving Architectures
author: Pramod Nair
summary: This book explores the complex security landscape of 5G networks and adjacent technologies such as MEC, SDN, NFV, and cloud-native architectures. It provides strategic and technical guidance for securing evolving telecom environments using Zero Trust principles, identity-aware access, and security automation.

title: CompTIA Security+ Study Guide, Sixth Edition
author: Emmett Dulaney, Chuck Easttom
summary: Aligned with the CompTIA Security+ SY0-401 exam, this sixth edition study guide covers core cybersecurity concepts including threats, vulnerabilities, risk management, cryptography, identity and access control, and network security. It includes review questions, hands-on exercises, and practice exams to help candidates prepare for certification.
notes: This edition is aligned with the retired SY0-401 exam objectives.

title: SQL Injection Attacks and Defense
author: Justin Clarke (Lead), Rodrigo Marcos Alvarez, Dave Hartley, Joseph Hemler, Alexander Kornbrust, Haroon Meer, Gary O’Leary-Steele, Alberto Revelli, Marco Slaviero, Dafydd Stuttard
summary: This book provides a comprehensive deep dive into SQL injection vulnerabilities, their exploitation, and effective defense strategies. Covering both offensive and defensive techniques, it’s authored by security professionals with real-world experience and includes practical examples and countermeasures.
notes: Justin Clarke served as lead author and technical editor. Includes contributions from 9 other security experts.

title: The Antivirus Hacker’s Handbook
author: Joxean Koret, Elias Bachaalany
summary: This advanced guide explores how antivirus engines work, how they can be reverse engineered, and how vulnerabilities within them can be exploited. It covers techniques for fuzzing, binary analysis, evasion, and crafting payloads that bypass traditional endpoint security controls.

title: The Basics of Information Security: Understanding the Fundamentals of InfoSec in Theory and Practice
author: Jason Andress
summary: This beginner-friendly book provides a clear and comprehensive introduction to the core principles of information security. Topics include risk management, access control, cryptography, and legal frameworks, making it ideal for students and professionals beginning their InfoSec journey.
notes: Technical Editor: Russ Rogers.

title: Thor's Microsoft Security Bible: A Collection of Practical Security Techniques
author: Timothy 'Thor' Mullen
summary: This comprehensive guide offers practical, real-world security techniques for protecting Microsoft environments. Covering Windows hardening, Active Directory, network security, PowerShell, and penetration testing strategies, it's geared toward IT pros, system administrators, and security engineers working in Microsoft-centric infrastructures.
notes: Technical Editor: Jeffrey W. Brown.

title: Mastering Windows Security and Hardening, Second Edition: Secure and Protect Your Windows Environment from Cyber Threats Using Zero-Trust Security Principles
author: Mark Dunkerley, Matt Tumbarello
summary: This second edition offers comprehensive, hands-on guidance for securing Windows environments. Emphasizing Zero Trust principles, the book covers configuration baselines, system hardening, access control, audit policies, and modern security tools such as Windows Defender, Group Policy, and Microsoft Endpoint Manager.

title: Zero Trust Architecture
author: Cindy Green-Ortiz, Brandon Fowler, David Houck, Hank Hensel, Patrick Lloyd, Andrew McDonald, Jason Frazier
summary: This book provides a detailed and practical guide to implementing Zero Trust security models in modern enterprise environments. Covering identity, segmentation, network policy enforcement, and threat response, it blends strategic guidance with technical detail using Cisco technologies and vendor-neutral frameworks.
notes: Contributors include certified professionals with CISSP, CISM, CCIE, CCNP Security, and other credentials. Intended for architects, engineers, and security leadership teams.

title: Information Security Handbook: Develop a Threat Model and Incident Response Strategy to Build a Strong Information Security Framework
author: Darren Death
summary: This handbook provides a practical approach to building a complete information security framework. It guides readers through establishing a threat model, developing incident response strategies, aligning to standards, and building a defensible InfoSec posture suitable for enterprise environments.

title: Computer Security Handbook, Sixth Edition
author: Seymour Bosworth, Michel E. Kabay, Eric Whyne (Editors)
summary: A comprehensive reference guide covering the full spectrum of computer security topics, including risk management, cryptography, network defense, cyber law, operations security, and organizational frameworks. This sixth edition features updated insights from dozens of contributing experts across government, academia, and industry.
notes: Edited volume with chapters by multiple subject matter experts. Frequently used in academic and certification programs.

title: The Art of Attack: Attacker Mindset for Security Professionals
author: Maxie Reynolds
summary: This book explores the attacker mindset and how understanding adversarial thinking can improve your approach to defense, testing, and system design. It blends behavioral psychology, red team operations, and real-world hacking insights to help professionals predict and outmaneuver threats.

title: Unauthorised Access: Physical Penetration Testing for IT Security Teams
author: Wil Allsopp
summary: This book explores the methods and mindset of physical penetration testing, showing how attackers bypass physical barriers to gain unauthorized access to systems and data. It covers tactics such as social engineering, lock picking, impersonation, and surveillance, offering security teams insights into hardening their physical defenses.

title: Social Engineering: The Science of Human Hacking
author: Christopher Hadnagy
summary: This book examines how attackers use psychological manipulation to exploit human behavior and gain unauthorized access to systems and data. It includes real-world case studies and teaches readers how to identify, defend against, and ethically simulate social engineering attacks.

title: Foundations of Information Security: A Straightforward Introduction
author: Jason Andress
summary: This beginner-friendly guide introduces the essential concepts of information security, including threat modeling, cryptography, authentication, access control, and governance. With clear language and real-world examples, it's an ideal starting point for students, professionals new to the field, or anyone seeking to understand cybersecurity basics.

title: Software Transparency: Supply Chain Security in an Era of a Software-Driven Society
author: Chris Hughes, Tony Turner
summary: This book explores the critical need for transparency and accountability in software development and distribution. It covers the rise of SBOMs (Software Bill of Materials), vulnerabilities in the software supply chain, and how organizations can adopt proactive governance and risk management practices to secure their digital ecosystems.

title: Enterprise Security: A Data-Centric Approach to Securing the Enterprise
author: Packt Publishing
summary: This book presents a holistic and strategic approach to securing enterprise environments by focusing on the data itself as the central asset. It covers data classification, access control, encryption, and monitoring practices to create a security architecture that prioritizes protecting sensitive information regardless of where it resides.
notes: Author(s) not listed individually; attributed to Packt Publishing.

title: Cryptography and Network Security: Principles and Practice, Fifth Edition
author: William Stallings
summary: This textbook introduces the fundamental principles of cryptography and network security. Topics include symmetric and public-key encryption, hashing, authentication protocols, IP security, TLS/SSL, and system security. The fifth edition incorporates updates on AES, SHA, digital signatures, and public key infrastructure.
notes: Widely adopted in academic and certification programs. Each edition reflects evolving standards and threat models.

title: The Art of Deception: Controlling the Human Element of Security
author: Kevin D. Mitnick, William L. Simon
summary: Through real-world case studies and fictionalized scenarios, this book reveals how social engineering tactics can be used to manipulate individuals and bypass security systems. It highlights the critical need for security awareness and training, showing how people—not just technology—are often the weakest link.
notes: Kevin Mitnick was one of the most well-known hackers in history; this book helped popularize the importance of social engineering defense.

title: Transformational Security Awareness: What Neuroscientists, Storytellers, and Marketers Can Teach Us About Driving Secure Behaviors
author: Perry Carpenter
summary: This book explores how to design and implement security awareness programs that actually change user behavior. Drawing on neuroscience, marketing, and storytelling, it offers a framework for creating engaging, emotionally resonant, and effective awareness training that moves users from passive knowledge to active security habits.

title: Threat Modeling: Designing for Security
author: Adam Shostack
summary: This practical guide teaches readers how to integrate threat modeling into software design and development. It covers methods like STRIDE, attack trees, and data flow analysis to proactively identify and mitigate security risks before deployment. Ideal for developers, architects, and security engineers.

title: Hacking a Terror Network: The Silent Threat of Covert Channels
author: Russ Rogers
summary: This book investigates the use of covert communication channels and steganography by terrorist organizations, offering a technical look at how such methods may be leveraged to evade detection. Blending real-world intelligence concerns with practical infosec techniques, it explores both offensive and defensive countermeasures against covert threats.
notes: Technical Editor: Matthew G. Devost. Focuses on the intersection of cybersecurity and counterterrorism.

title: Cybersecurity and Third-Party Risk: Third Party Threat Hunting
author: Gregory C. Rasner
summary: This book offers practical strategies for managing and mitigating cybersecurity risks introduced by third-party vendors. It includes methods for evaluating partner security postures, integrating third-party threat intelligence, and applying threat hunting techniques across the extended enterprise.

title: The Security Culture Playbook
author: Perry Carpenter, Kai Roer
summary: This book provides a strategic and research-backed approach to building and sustaining a strong security culture. It introduces frameworks and metrics for assessing security behaviors, shaping employee attitudes, and embedding cybersecurity into the organizational DNA. Ideal for security leaders and awareness professionals.

title: Secrets and Lies: Digital Security in a Networked World, 15th Anniversary Edition
author: Bruce Schneier
summary: This updated edition of Bruce Schneier’s classic work examines how security really works in the modern world. Blending technical clarity with human-centric analysis, it addresses topics such as cryptography, system design, trust models, and the economics of security. Ideal for both technical professionals and policy thinkers.
notes: 15th Anniversary Edition with updates reflecting the evolution of digital security since the original 2000 publication.

title: Windows Forensics Cookbook: 61 Recipes to Help You Analyze Windows Systems
author: Oleg Skulkin, Scar de Courcier
summary: This practical guide provides 61 step-by-step forensic recipes for investigating Windows systems. Covering topics such as registry analysis, memory forensics, event log review, malware detection, and timeline creation, it's designed for digital forensic investigators and incident response teams seeking hands-on expertise.

title: Digital Forensics and Incident Response: An Intelligent Way to Respond to Attacks
author: Gerard Johansen
summary: This book provides a practical guide to digital forensics and incident response, covering the entire lifecycle from preparation to investigation and remediation. Topics include threat detection, log analysis, evidence acquisition, malware analysis, and post-incident reporting, with real-world case studies and tools.

title: Practical Windows Forensics: Leverage the Power of Digital Forensics for Windows Systems
author: Ayman Shaaban, Konstantin Sapronov
summary: This hands-on guide explores digital forensics on Windows systems through practical, real-world use cases. Covering topics such as memory dumps, registry analysis, file system examination, malware artifacts, and user activity reconstruction, the book is ideal for forensic investigators and incident responders.

title: Practical Mobile Forensics, Third Edition
author: Rohit Tamma, Oleg Skulkin, Heather Mahalik, Satish Bommisetty
summary: This comprehensive guide to mobile device forensics provides step-by-step procedures and case studies for analyzing iOS, Android, and Windows Phone devices. It includes tools and techniques for data acquisition, artifact analysis, app forensics, and reporting. Ideal for digital forensic investigators and incident responders.
notes: Covers third edition; newer editions may exist.

title: Practical Forensic Imaging: Securing Digital Evidence with Linux Tools
author: Bruce Nikkel
summary: This practical guide focuses on creating secure forensic images using open-source Linux tools. It covers disk imaging techniques, evidence handling, chain of custody, hash verification, and best practices for acquiring digital evidence in legally defensible ways. Ideal for forensic professionals and incident responders working in Linux-heavy environments.

title: Learning Network Forensics: Identify and Safeguard Your Network Against Both Internal and External Threats, Hackers, and Malware Attacks
author: Samir Datt
summary: This book introduces network forensics techniques to detect, investigate, and respond to internal and external cyber threats. It covers packet analysis, intrusion detection, traffic flow interpretation, and forensic investigation tools to track attacks and malicious activity over networks.

title: Tribe of Hackers: Cybersecurity Advice from the Best Hackers in the World
author: Marcus J. Carey, Jennifer Jin
summary: This book is a collection of interviews and advice from dozens of cybersecurity professionals across disciplines. Topics include career growth, threat landscapes, ethical hacking, incident response, and navigating the evolving field of security. It's a rich resource for aspiring and seasoned professionals alike.
notes: First in a multi-volume series. Other volumes include 'Tribe of Hackers Red Team', 'Blue Team', and 'Security Leaders'.

title: Tribe of Hackers Blue Team
author: Marcus J. Carey, Jennifer Jin
summary: This volume of the Tribe of Hackers series focuses on blue teamers—defenders who protect, detect, and respond to cyber threats. Through interviews with industry experts, the book explores real-world experiences, tool recommendations, team dynamics, and career advice for security operations professionals.
notes: Part of the Tribe of Hackers series, with companion volumes for Red Team, Security Leaders, and the original edition.

title: Tribe of Hackers Red Team: Tribal Knowledge from the Best in Offensive Cybersecurity
author: Marcus J. Carey, Jennifer Jin
summary: This volume brings together offensive security experts to discuss their approach to red teaming, adversary simulation, exploit development, and more. Through in-depth interviews, it offers practical advice, tool recommendations, and ethical perspectives for aspiring and practicing red teamers.
notes: Part of the Tribe of Hackers series. Focuses exclusively on offensive cybersecurity roles and mindsets.

title: Tribe of Hackers: Security Leaders
author: Marcus J. Carey, Jennifer Jin
summary: This volume in the Tribe of Hackers series compiles insights from cybersecurity executives and thought leaders. Covering topics like security governance, strategic planning, team building, and policy influence, it's an essential guide for professionals transitioning into leadership or CISO-level roles.
notes: Completes the Tribe of Hackers series with a focus on leadership and strategic cybersecurity planning.

title: The Security Development Lifecycle: A Process for Developing Demonstrably More Secure Software
author: Michael Howard, Steve Lipner
summary: This foundational book introduces the Security Development Lifecycle (SDL), a comprehensive process used by Microsoft to design, develop, and test secure software. It outlines security requirements, threat modeling, secure coding practices, and validation techniques that help reduce vulnerabilities throughout the development process.
notes: One of the earliest formal frameworks for integrating security into the software development lifecycle. Still relevant for legacy systems and secure coding practices.

title: The Art of Memory Forensics: Detecting Malware and Threats in Windows, Linux, and Mac Memory
author: Michael Hale Ligh, Andrew Case, Jamie Levy, AAron Walters
summary: This comprehensive guide teaches investigators how to detect and analyze threats hiding in memory across Windows, Linux, and Mac systems. It focuses on memory acquisition, forensic imaging, malware analysis, and real-world case studies using tools like Volatility. A must-read for DFIR and malware analysts.
notes: Developed by the creators of the Volatility Framework. Essential for serious memory and malware forensics.

title: Cyberjutsu: Cybersecurity for the Modern Ninja
author: Ben McCarty
summary: Combining the principles of ninjutsu with modern cybersecurity techniques, this book teaches how to think like an attacker—stealthy, agile, and strategic. It covers topics like recon, pivoting, deception, and stealth operations in both red and blue team contexts, offering a philosophical and tactical guide to cyber warfare.
notes: Blends traditional martial strategy with cyber operations. Great for red teamers and defenders alike.
